title: CVPR_2011_10_abs

sentences.text: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other .
This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition .
This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points .
It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other .
We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors .
We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

summary: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other . This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition . This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points . It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other . We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors . We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

Predicate-causes.label: causes
Predicate-causes.description: The predicate 'causes' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's existence or occurrence leads to or results in the state of being described by the object. In general, it implies a direct influence or effect on the object.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: To present means to introduce or offer something as a solution, explanation, or representation. In this sense, it connects the subject (the entity providing the presentation) with the object (what is being presented), indicating that the subject has identified and offered the object as a relevant concept, idea, or approach.

Predicate-detects.label: detects
Predicate-detects.description: The predicate 'detects' indicates the subject's ability to recognize or identify a specific phenomenon, characteristic, or pattern in its object. It implies that the subject has the capacity to perceive and distinguish the object from other possibilities.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject possesses or owns the object. This possession can be physical, abstract, conceptual, or even metaphorical. The connection between the subject and object implies that the subject has control over, is responsible for, or is characterized by the presence of the object.

Predicate-models.label: models
Predicate-models.description: The predicate 'models' represents a relationship where the subject (It) serves as an exemplar or representation of the object (Reflections), possibly suggesting that It embodies, illustrates, or mirrors aspects of Reflections.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates the existence or occurrence of something in the current time frame. It suggests that the subject has access to or possesses the object at this moment, emphasizing its relevance and significance.

Predicate-based_on_combining_a_set_of_we.label: based on combining a set of weak detectors
Predicate-based_on_combining_a_set_of_we.description: The predicate 'based on combining a set of weak detectors' indicates that the subject (a strong detector) relies on or derives its strength from the combination of multiple weaker detectors, which are represented by the object (set of weak detectors).

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: To generate means to produce or create something from a given source or set of inputs. The subject is responsible for providing the necessary information or context, and the predicate 'generate' connects this input to the object by transforming it into a new form, often with some level of organization, structure, or meaning.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a specific instance or subclass of the object concept. In other words, it denotes a hierarchical relationship where the subject is more specialized than the object.
